docs.title: Welcome to Clarity Docs
docs.text: This is the homepage of the Clarity Documentation site. Here you can navigate through all the documentation for workflows, health and safety, ISO standards, and more.

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• Workflows – Learn about processes and best practices.
  • Health & Safety – Guidelines and procedures for a safe workplace.
  • ISO Standards – Access ISO 9001, 27001, and 45001 documentation.

docs.title: About This Site
docs.text:
Clarity Docs is designed to provide easy-to-navigate, up-to-date documentation for your organization.

  • Editable Markdown – Admins can update content directly in GitHub.
  • Structured Navigation – Sidebar provides quick access to all sections.
  • Responsive Design – Works on desktop and mobile devices.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Use the sidebar to navigate to the section you want.
  2. Click any page to read the documentation.
  3. Admins can edit .md files directly to update content.

This is a placeholder homepage. Content can be expanded with organization-specific information, announcements, or links to resources.

docs.title: Health & Safety
docs.text: This page provides an overview of the Occupational Health & Safety (OHS) policies and procedures within Clarity Docs.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: Health and safety are critical to maintaining a safe working environment. This page outlines general guidance and procedures to protect employees, contractors, and visitors.

docs.title: 2. Key Policies
docs.text:
• Workplace Safety – Follow all safety rules, wear protective equipment, and report hazards immediately.
  • Emergency Procedures – Know emergency exits, evacuation routes, and contact points for incidents.
  • Incident Reporting – Report accidents, near-misses, or unsafe conditions promptly.
  • Training & Awareness – Complete all mandatory health and safety training programs.

docs.title: 3. Example Procedures
docs.text:
1. Incident Reporting Procedure
  2. Identify and document the incident
  3. Notify the supervisor or safety officer
  4. Conduct investigation and corrective action

  5. Record the outcome in the system

  6. Fire Safety Procedure

  7. Know the location of fire extinguishers and alarms
  8. Follow evacuation routes

  9. Participate in fire drills regularly

  10. Equipment Safety Checks

  11. Inspect tools and machinery before use
  12. Ensure safety guards and personal protective equipment (PPE) are in place
  13. Report any faults or hazards immediately

docs.title: 4. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Always follow documented procedures
  • Encourage a culture of safety and awareness
  • Continuously review and improve safety measures
  • Maintain clear records of training, incidents, and audits

docs.title: 5. References
docs.text:
• ISO 45001 Occupational Health & Safety
  • Internal OHS Guidelines and Procedures (update as needed)

This is a placeholder page for demonstration purposes. Content can be expanded with organization-specific policies, procedures, and examples.

docs.title: Workflows
docs.text: This page provides an overview of the key workflows within Clarity Docs. It is designed to guide users through standard processes and best practices.

docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text: Workflows help ensure consistency and efficiency across the organization. They define the steps, responsibilities, and timelines for common processes.

docs.title: 2. Example Workflows
docs.text:
Here are a few example workflows you might find in the organization:

  1. Document Approval Workflow
  2. Create or update a document
  3. Submit for review
  4. Approver reviews and either approves or requests changes

  5. Document is published once approved

  6. Incident Reporting Workflow

  7. Employee reports an incident
  8. Safety officer reviews and categorizes the report
  9. Investigation is conducted

  10. Corrective actions are implemented

  11. Training & Onboarding Workflow

  12. New employee is assigned mandatory training
  13. Completion is tracked in the system
  14. Feedback is collected and reviewed

docs.title: 3. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Always follow the documented steps in each workflow.
  • Keep records of approvals, incidents, and training completions.
  • Review workflows regularly to identify areas for improvement.

docs.title: 4. Getting Started
docs.text:
• Use the sidebar to navigate to other workflows or related documentation.
  • Admins can update workflows directly by editing .md files in GitHub.
  • Ensure all updates are reviewed and tested before publishing.

This is a placeholder page for demonstration purposes. Real workflows should be documented and linked to your internal procedures.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: A brief overview of the Risk Register module: - Tracks and manages risks across various disciplines (Quality, Health & Safety, Environmental, Information) - Allows creation, review, and mitigation of risks

docs.title: Page Layout
docs.text: Highlights: - Risk list / table - Filter and search options - Buttons for "Add Risk", "Import", "Export" - Column headers: Risk Title, Discipline, Category, Type, Rating, Mitigation, Owner, Review Frequency, Status

docs.title: Key Actions
docs.text:
Users can perform the following actions: - View list of risks - Add a new risk - Open details drawer for a risk - Edit or delete an existing risk - Assign an owner or management program - Add mitigations

Example: Click “Add Risk” to open the creation modal. Click on a row to view risk details.

docs.title: Add New Risk
docs.text:
Key Fields: - Risk Title: Brief descriptive name of the risk - Discipline: ISO discipline the risk belongs to (e.g., Quality, H&S, Environmental, Information) - Category / Type: Type of risk (Financial, Operational, etc.) - Description: Detailed explanation of the risk - Champion / Owner: Responsible employee - Review Frequency: How often the risk is reviewed - Probability / Impact: Likelihood and potential impact of the risk - Mitigation Actions: Steps to reduce risk - Management Program: Program associated with this risk

Optional: Include short example if necessary.

docs.title: Risk Details Drawer
docs.text:
Information Shown: - Probability, Impact, Rating - Description - Risk Mitigation (mitigated Probability / Impact / Rating) - Mitigation Actions - Management Program - Status

Click on a risk row in the main table to open the drawer.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Certain ISO standards (14001, 45001) use the same Risk Register module; minor differences may include risk types or categories.
  • Permissions may vary by role:
  • Admin / QA: Can create, edit, and delete risks
  • Level 2 Managers: Can add or edit risks assigned to their team
  • Level 1 Users: View only

docs.title: ISO 27001: Information Security Management System
docs.text: Welcome to the ISO 27001 documentation page. This page outlines the key principles, requirements, and processes for maintaining a compliant Information Security Management System (ISMS).

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: ISO 27001 is an international standard for managing information security. It provides a framework for organizations to protect sensitive information, manage risks, and ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data.

docs.title: 2. Scope
docs.text:
ISO 27001 applies to any organization that handles information requiring protection. Key areas include:

  • Risk management and assessment
  • Security policies and procedures
  • Access control and data protection
  • Compliance with legal and regulatory requirements

docs.title: 3. Key Principles
docs.text:
ISO 27001 focuses on several core principles:

  1. Confidentiality – Ensuring information is accessible only to those authorized.
  2. Integrity – Safeguarding the accuracy and completeness of information.
  3. Availability – Ensuring authorized users have access to information when needed.
  4. Risk management – Identifying, assessing, and mitigating security risks.
  5. Continuous improvement – Regularly updating the ISMS to address new threats.

docs.title: 4. Opportunities & Risks
docs.text:
Organizations must identify potential opportunities to strengthen information security and risks that could compromise it. Examples include:

  • Opportunities:
  • Implementing multi-factor authentication
  • Conducting regular security awareness training
  • Risks:
  • Cyberattacks or data breaches
  • Unauthorized access to confidential data

docs.title: 5. Documentation & Records
docs.text:
ISO 27001 requires maintaining documented information to support the ISMS:

  • Information security policies
  • Procedures for incident management and business continuity
  • Records of risk assessments, audits, and corrective actions

docs.title: 6. Continual Improvement
docs.text:
A robust ISMS is never static. Organizations are expected to:

  • Monitor security controls and processes
  • Conduct internal audits
  • Review incidents and lessons learned
  • Implement corrective and preventive actions

docs.title: 7. References
docs.text:
• ISO 27001 Standard Overview
  • ISO Information Security Guidance Documents

This content is for demonstration purposes and can be expanded with your organization-specific policies, workflows, and examples.

docs.title: ISO 45001: Occupational Health and Safety Management System
docs.text: Welcome to the ISO 45001 documentation page. This page outlines the key principles, requirements, and processes for maintaining a compliant Occupational Health and Safety Management System (OHSMS).

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: ISO 45001 is an international standard for occupational health and safety. It provides a framework for organizations to prevent work-related injuries, improve employee safety, and ensure a safe working environment.

docs.title: 2. Scope
docs.text:
ISO 45001 applies to organizations of all sizes and industries. Key areas include:

  • Risk assessment and hazard identification
  • Safety policies and procedures
  • Employee training and awareness
  • Compliance with legal and regulatory requirements

docs.title: 3. Key Principles
docs.text:
ISO 45001 emphasizes several core principles:

  1. Leadership and commitment – Management must actively lead safety initiatives.
  2. Worker participation – Employees should be involved in health and safety decisions.
  3. Hazard identification and risk control – Proactively prevent incidents.
  4. Continual improvement – Regularly monitor, review, and improve the OHSMS.
  5. Compliance with legal requirements – Ensure all applicable laws and regulations are met.

docs.title: 4. Opportunities & Risks
docs.text:
Organizations should identify opportunities to improve safety and risks that could lead to accidents. Examples include:

  • Opportunities:
  • Implementing ergonomic workplace solutions
  • Conducting regular safety drills
  • Risks:
  • Workplace accidents or near-misses
  • Non-compliance with safety regulations

docs.title: 5. Documentation & Records
docs.text:
ISO 45001 requires maintaining documented information to support the OHSMS:

  • Health and safety policies
  • Risk assessments and hazard logs
  • Records of training, audits, and corrective actions
  • Incident reports and investigations

docs.title: 6. Continual Improvement
docs.text:
A strong OHSMS requires ongoing effort. Organizations are expected to:

  • Monitor safety performance indicators
  • Conduct internal safety audits
  • Review incidents and feedback
  • Implement corrective and preventive actions

docs.title: 7. References
docs.text:
• ISO 45001 Standard Overview
  • ISO Occupational Health & Safety Guidance

This content is for demonstration purposes and can be expanded with your organization-specific safety policies, procedures, and examples.

docs.title: ISO 9001: Quality Management System
docs.text: Welcome to the ISO 9001 documentation page. This page outlines the key principles, requirements, and processes for maintaining a compliant Quality Management System (QMS).

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: ISO 9001 is an international standard that specifies requirements for a quality management system (QMS). Organizations use the standard to demonstrate their ability to consistently provide products and services that meet customer and regulatory requirements.

docs.title: 2. Scope
docs.text:
The ISO 9001 standard applies to any organization, regardless of its size or industry. Key areas include:

  • Customer focus and satisfaction
  • Leadership and management commitment
  • Process approach and continual improvement
  • Risk-based thinking

docs.title: 3. Key Principles
docs.text:
ISO 9001 is based on several quality management principles:

  1. Customer focus – Meeting and exceeding customer expectations.
  2. Leadership – Establishing unity of purpose and direction.
  3. Engagement of people – Competent, empowered, and engaged employees at all levels.
  4. Process approach – Understanding activities as processes that link together.
  5. Improvement – Ongoing enhancement of overall performance.
  6. Evidence-based decision making – Decisions based on analysis of data.
  7. Relationship management – Sustained success through stakeholder engagement.

docs.title: 4. Opportunities & Risks
docs.text:
Organizations must identify potential opportunities to improve quality and risks that could impact compliance. Examples include:

  • Opportunities:
  • Streamlining internal processes
  • Training programs to improve skill levels
  • Risks:
  • Supplier non-conformance
  • Regulatory changes affecting operations

docs.title: 5. Documentation & Records
docs.text:
ISO 9001 requires maintaining documented information to support the QMS:

  • Quality manual (optional but recommended)
  • Procedures and work instructions
  • Records of training, audits, and corrective actions

docs.title: 6. Continual Improvement
docs.text:
A successful QMS is never static. Organizations are expected to:

  • Monitor processes and performance
  • Conduct internal audits
  • Review customer feedback
  • Implement corrective and preventive actions

docs.title: 7. References
docs.text:
• ISO 9001:2015 Standard Overview
  • ISO QMS Guidance Documents

This content is for demonstration purposes and can be expanded with your organization-specific policies, workflows, and examples.
